text:
(soft music playing)
- My name is Rola Dali,
and I'm a data scientist at Kyndryl,

the world's largest IT
infrastructure services provider.

So I started with the cloud
as a genomics researcher.

My field of study is
chromatin architecture.

It's the study of how the
human genome folds in the cell.

After 15 years in academia,
I had moved into industry,

and industry relied on the
cloud much more heavily
than it relied on on-premise servers.

And that's when I realized
I really needed to learn

cloud computing, and
that's how it all started.
So about two years ago now,
there were several big shifts in my life.
I had come right out of maternity leave.
The pandemic had just hit and I had left
academia for industry.

And so it was a time of
a lot of confusion to me.
I wasn't feeling comfortable,
and I needed something to focus on.
And so I picked AWS certifications.
And going through the certifications,
it really helped me a lot,

because it gave me the confidence
to plow through industry

and feel more at home
with cloud resources.

(soft music continues)
And it also helped me

get out of that maternity
leave feeling, right?

Like I'm back as a professional
mother, I'm back there,
I'm doing my work.

I started with the AWS
architect because it was

the base certification that
gave a holistic overview

of the AWS ecosystem, and
that's where it all started.
I used AWS Skill Builder free resources
as part of my studying plan.
I was really surprised at how well curated
and thought out content was,

and how much supporting material
AWS makes freely available.
I would work my job the eight hours,
and then I would spend time with my kids
that the time that they came

from school all the way
till when they went to bed.

And then after that,
I would set up my tea,

I would put on my
computer, put on my music,

and I would just go
through and read about AWS
and all of the different services.

(soft music continues)
The certifications

helped me do my job in that
they give me a better overview
of all of the tools available to me.

It also helps me complete
projects a lot faster,
because I know how to troubleshoot faster.

The plan is to take all
12 AWS certifications
before the end of the year,

so I'm doing that right
now, one after the other.
This is gonna signify a milestone for me
moving from academia to industry.
